thread.title: Victorian man jailed for nine years for stepping on, killing toddler
thread.title_full: Victorian man jailed for nine years for stepping on, killing toddler

title: Victorian man jailed for nine years for stepping on, killing toddler
text:
Victorian man jailed for nine years for stepping on, killing toddler in spontaneous act of violence By Elias Clure Updated February 24, 2017 15:52:47 Map: Melbourne 3000 
A Horsham man has been sentenced to nine years and six months' jail for killing his ex-partner's toddler by stepping on her in a spontaneous act of violence. 
The Victorian Supreme Court was told Harley Woodford, 22, was at home alone with three-year-old Bella Lawrence when he tripped over her while she was playing on the floor, lost his temper and put his full weight on her stomach in western Victoria in September 2015. 
Woodford then put the girl to bed and told her not to tell her mother, Angie Roberts, what had happened. 
The court was told Ms Roberts took her daughter to hospital the following day after she began to appear limp, pale and incommunicative. 
Bella was unconscious and unresponsive on arrival and died a short time later from internal injuries caused by blunt force trauma. 
In sentencing, Justice Jane Dixon told the court Woodford did not initially admit to having caused the injuries which led to her death, and was treated as a grieving parent. 
"The objective gravity of your momentary expression of brute force towards a defenceless child was magnified by your attempts to avoid responsibility by concealing what you had done from her mother, rather than ensuring necessary medical attention," she said. 
It was not until April of the following year, when he was informed by Ms Roberts that there would be further investigations into the death, that Woodford admitted to having stepped on the young child. 
He pleaded guilty to child homicide during one of his first appearances in court. 
Justice Dixon said the toddler "languished at home in pain and misery". 
"Whatever future you do have when you are released, you will be forever burdened by the knowledge of what you did to Bella, a defenceless child who looked up to you for care and protection," she said. 
"You betrayed the faith that Ms Roberts placed in you to act as a parent while she was absent from the home." Family remember 'angel in disguise' 
Speaking outside court, Bella's father Jonathan Lawrence described the sentence as "disgusting". 
"I feel that today's sentence will never be enough to put my family at peace with what has happened," he said. 
"My daughter never made it to his minimum term, which just makes me sick. 
"We will never see her face again, never hear her voice again, he took my daughter who I always knew was an angel in disguise." 
Bella's mother broke down several times during the sentencing. 
Woodford will be eligible parole in six and a half years.
